comments.commentBody: My family went through the legal process to immigrate. In 1953 my parents came first, they rented a house, bought cars etc. - In 1954 I followed last, and was soon drafted (those days military service was equally a duty for American and immigrants). I was glad to serve because it made feel that I belong here. In fact, I'm proud of my military service, I feel it the draft should be restored, not only because it would reduce teen and young adult unemployment, but, because it unites us all. That's my short history, and I think it should be the history of all immigrants, whether they come through the front door as I did, or the back door as these 11 million our system forces to lurk in the shadows, most of them productive tax payers. So much for how documented immigrants should feel about the undocumented. As to other countries that have had to incorporate thousands and foreign workers into their economies and societies, whether they came by the tens of thousands in boat loads, with and without papers, I'd cite Germany, Holland, Belgium, France, Spain and Italy. For me, the important thing is that they should be (or become) constructive working as well as professional law abiding people that will lift themselves and our Country higher, and love and care for these United States.

Ross, I agree with you in part. After all, Leigh mentions the Confederate sources with a vague reference to their conclusions. But he does not analyze or critique these accounts, as he properly does with the union sources. At the same time, those union sources themselves provide some evidence that Sherman acquiesced in the physical destruction of Atlanta.

Evaluating this scorched earth policy is more difficult. Sherman (along with Lincoln and Grant) apparently believed that only by making civilians suffer could the union armies destroy morale and thereby force an end to a war that cost 750,000 military deaths. I think one's attitude toward Sherman's actions in Georgia depend upon whether the general's rationale is considered valid. I tend to think it was, but the events in Georgia still form part of what was clearly an American tragedy, even if a necessary one.

Having been a single mother/photojournalist for over a quarter-century, I had a hard time relating to this article. For one thing, nearly all the women interviewed had babies or toddlers, thus hadn't been juggling for very long; and also seemed to have supportive husbands and/or nannies to help them. School-aged children can't be toted along on assignments.  Even the statement, "A generation of female photographers is looking to one another for advice and support as they raise children while still going on assignment overseas" strains credulity for me. I realize that I'm 20 years older than these women, but even now, the younger female newspaper photogs I know are afraid that having kids will hurt their careers--not to mention that many news organizations don't even treat women right, whether they're moms or not. Bottom line is that for me, this article doesn't at all reflect what it's like to be a mother and a photojournalist, 25 years ago or now. I could be wrong, but I think I'm the only female photojournalist to win a (non-staff) Pulitzer Prize while raising kids and definitely the only single mom...and while nothing is impossible, the degree of difficulty is off the charts!  I don't regret for a minute doing both; and being a parent has definitely made me a better photographer.  While I'm happy that the women interviewed here are doing well, it would have been great if the article had gone deeper and presented a more accurate picture of what this is really like.

Re "being forced to buy something so expensive": you will most assuredly be happy that you were forced to if someone in your family falls seriously ill or has a serious accident.  Amazing that you seem so oblivious to the possibility that you might then lose everything you have and more without the protection of "expensive" health insurance.

Blackdog,

No, "forced to buy something so expensive" as in we had coverage before, and the prices for ACA plans are astronomical. Amazing that YOU seem so oblivious to the real issues this law causes for some of us. I guess we matter less?

You had coverage before, analogous to your current coverage, on the open market and not through an employer?  Good for you!  You must have a very healthy family with no pre-existing conditions and no serious injuries ... ever.  That's very fortunate for you.  That is also no reason to use your (very anomalous) experiences as a reason to change a system that has, overall, helped many more people than it has hurt.

"The law is also designed to make insurance affordable, with no one being required to spend more than 8 percent of his or her income of health insurance."

You say this like it's no big deal! To put it in perspective for my family, the premium quotes we have received thus far are double the amount I spend on food for our clan of 4 each month, and that's just to cover my husband. If we had to pay 8%, it would be triple. Our only monthly expense higher than food is our mortgage. Why? Because we spend our money carefully and wisely.

Being forced to buy something so expensive (especially when we were doing just fine before) doesn't seem like that great of a reward for all the years of hard work and diligence on our part.

Jackie:  Okay, I guess we can be literal and stipulate that if no more children were born, eventually the human race would die off.  But the claim to be selflessly perpetuating humanity is usually just a ruse for "I want to have children, so everyone else should subsidize my choice."  I'll stand by my comment that the world would be a better place if the human population went back to its level in year zero A.D.  Except for the most exceptional and productive among us, you're not "taking one for the team" when you have kids.
Earl W., that is a ridiculous argument because if people 2000 years ago had not had any children, then you yourself wouldn't be here today to tell us that children are not essential.

Suzanna:  Try to follow the conversation.  It's possible to perpetuate the human race, but not have it grow in size.  I'm suggesting the world would be a wealthier, happier, and more ecologically-sustainable place if the world's population was much smaller.  We can start by not subsidizing the creation of more people through the tax code or workplace rules.

I'm always bemused by the comments on stories like this, emphasizing that "having children is a lifestyle choice."

For God's sake. Raising children isn't just some particularly expensive and demanding hobby. Aside from being essential to the continuance of society, it's the most profoundly life-altering act anyone can undertake. If you don't want or cannot have children, your life will be profoundly different from that of parents. This is not a value judgment.

All of society has an interest in the successful raising of children. The costs to society as a whole of badly-raised children are staggering.

I didn't understand what it meant to have a child until I did have one. Children need the love and attention of both parents. In single-parent households, children will especially need the loving attention of other meaningful adults. Fathers who do not make the financial and status sacrifices to be with their children will find the latter parts of their lives not as rewarding as they envisioned in their hard-driving years, but by that time it will be too late. Until society as a whole recognizes the value of parenting, why should the average company care?

Responding to various readers:

Paul: For the bonus -- a European roulette wheel has 36 numbers plus 0.

Bingo! (Oops, wrong game.) But it's a bit retro of you to suggest that 0 isn't a number. Even stodgy old http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/0_(number) fails to condemn as Original Research the assertion that 0 is a number. (The article goes on to muddle the distinction between the number 0 and the digit (placeholder) 0, but perhaps the history of this distinction smacks of Original Research.

Dr W: Right: http://www.predictem.com/roulette/wheel.php

But -- is a wedge space on such a wheel considered an "object"?

Probably not. But what is an angle? The thing you actually measure is not the wedge space between two rays. It's the arc of the circle cut off by the rays. Where is the 1 degree angle on a protractor? I claim it's the arc between consecutive ticks.

Mark: I'm sure that's the answer. But for one thing a roulette wheel is not planar -- and so the angles will be smaller -- and for another the separators do not meet in the center, so there's an "angle" only in a pretty unusual sense.

It may be unusual, but it shouldn't be.

Steven Lord: That's it, as per the hint-- the nearer US wheels have zero _and_ double zero giving them 38 slots or Pi/19 angles.

Bingo again. Er, sorry. Actually, Gary A found http://www.businesslinks.cz/main/best-places-to-play-roulette/ , which lists (and recommends) a few 37-slot wheels in Las Vegas.


Dr W: In a plan view (looking down) the sides of (or to be more precise, vertical planar boundaries between) the numbers and slots on a roulette wheel -- when extended -- will meet at the wheel center in a single point. Those extensions divide 360° into the specified angles.

Yes, but I accept your earlier objection that this isn't "physical".

Seth Cohen: This is sort of a cop-out answer to the bonus puzzle, but the hands on a clock with a minute hand and an hour hand that both move smoothly will eventually form any angle you want.

You might find yourself closer to operating scissors or a flapping jaw. But this cop-out raises
the interesting question of whether an event of truly zero duration has any physical reality.

Anyway, great answers everybody. (Although we should make sure the Russians don't have 37-shot revolvers for the mildly suicidal)-:
--Bill Gosper
